s.text: Occasionally, we doctors find convincing evidence of abuse: cigarette burns, X-rays showing multiple fractures of varying age, bruises that trace the outline of a coat hanger, a stockinglike burn suggesting a foot plunged into and held down in hot liquid.

It was, I knew, a suspicious story--an unwitnessed fall resulting in a bad fracture.
The numbers certainly make the Noe deaths suspicious.
Eight deaths in one family was highly suspicious, and Noe was the only person present when each of the children died.

For example, we know that single parents have almost double the risk of being abusive, poor families almost 16 times the likelihood.
Two suggestive findings are that sleeping on soft bedding and sleeping face down both increase a baby's risk of sudden death.
It's easy for parents to feel self-righteous when doctors ask questions as if they're cops, but as advanced as medicine has become, questions are still our main diagnostic test for abuse.
